concept.title: Glossaries
concept.shortdesc: Learn the benefits of using glossaries in your localization process.

section.title: Consistency
section.p: Glossaries are the easiest way to improve consistency of translated text. Different translators (or even the same translator at different times) can translate the same term in various ways. Giving them a glossary of approved translations can increase the consistency of terminology in one project or different projects concerning the same product.
section.note: Most tools enable automatic terminology checks to ensure a translator has used terms from the glossary. Although such checks are less useful in languages in which the same word can have various grammatical forms .

section.title: Non-translatable text
section.p: Glossaries can also specify text that should not be translated, such as brand names.

section.title: Forbidden terms
section.p: If you don't want a given term to be tarnslated in a particular way, a glossary is also a good place to specify that. For example, the word "pacemaker" can be translated into Polish as "rozrusznik", but you may want translators to use the less colloquial "stymulator" instead.

section.title: Context
section.p: Glossaries can also provide context for each term, such as its definition.

section.title: Format
section.p: Glossaries (called term bases) can be developed directly in a CAT tool. Most CAT tools have their own term base format, but you can use a universal format called TermBase eXchange (TBX) to exchange term bases between different tools.
You can also prepare a glossary as a file in a spreadsheet editor and then import it into a CAT tool.
